title: Present Tense - Regular Verbs
explanation:
In Dutch, you conjugate verbs by adding endings to the stem of the verb. The stem is obtained by removing -en from the infinitive (whole verb).

For example: 'werken' → stem = 'werk'

For regular verbs in the present tense, use these endings:
• ik: stem (no ending)
• jij/je: stem + t
• hij/zij/het: stem + t
• wij/we: whole verb (infinitive)
• jullie: whole verb (infinitive)
• zij: whole verb (infinitive)

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'maken' (to make): Ik ... elke dag huiswerk.
exercises.explanation: For 'ik' use just the stem: maak (maken - en = maak)

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'wonen' (to live): Hij ... in Utrecht.
exercises.explanation: For 'hij' use stem + t: woon + t = woont

exercises.question: How do you say 'I work in Amsterdam' in Dutch?
exercises.explanation: Ik werk in Amsterdam - 'werk' is the stem form for 'ik'
exercises.hint: Remember: 'ik' uses the stem without any ending

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'studeren' (to study): Zij ... elke avond.
exercises.explanation: For 'zij' use stem + t: studeer + t = studeert

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'koken' (to cook): Wij ... samen.
exercises.explanation: For 'wij' use the whole verb: koken

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'lezen' (to read): Jullie ... veel boeken.
exercises.explanation: For 'jullie' use the whole verb: lezen

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'schrijven' (to write): Ik ... een brief.
exercises.explanation: For 'ik' use just the stem: schrijf (schrijven - en = schrijf)

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'luisteren' (to listen): Zij ... naar muziek.
exercises.explanation: For 'zij' use stem + t: luister + t = luistert

exercises.question: How do you say 'We live in Rotterdam' in Dutch?
exercises.explanation: Wij wonen in Rotterdam - 'wonen' is the infinitive for 'wij'

exercises.question: Conjugation of 'beginnen' (to begin): Het ... om 8 uur.
exercises.explanation: For 'het' use stem + t: begin + t = begint

commonMistakes.explanation: For 'ik' don't add -t, just use the stem
For 'hij/zij' you must add -t to the stem
For 'wij' use the whole verb (infinitive), not stem + t

tips: Practice with the stem first: write the infinitive and remove -en
In questions with 'jij' you get no extra -t: 'Werk jij?' (not 'Werkt jij?')
Common verbs to practice: werken, wonen, leren, maken, koken, lezen
Watch out for verbs ending in -eren: studeren → studeer (stem)
